article:
'Bacterial nanowires' (also known as microbial nanowires) are electrically
conductive appendages produced by a number of bacteria most notably from (but
not exclusive to) the [[Geobacter]] and [[Shewanella]] genera. G. Reguera et al., Nature 435, 1098 (2005) Y. A. Gorby et al., Proceedings of the National Academy of
Sciences of the United States of America 103, 11358 (2006). Conductive
nanowires have also been confirmed in the oxygenic cyanobacterium Synechocystis
PCC6803 and a thermophilic, methanogenic coculture consisting of Pelotomaculum
thermopropionicum and Methanothermobacter thermoautotrophicus.
